Returns the "sign" of the integer as another integer: `1` for positive numbers,
`-1` for negative numbers, and `0` for `0`.

type: ℤ → ℤ
name: Int.sign
docString:
Returns the "sign" of the integer as another integer: `1` for positive numbers,
`-1` for negative numbers, and `0` for `0`.

For any nontrivially normed field `𝕜`, normed additive commutative group `E`, normed space `E` over `𝕜`, and topological space `H`, the function `I` from `𝕜` to `E` defined in a Model With Corners `I` of types `𝕜`, `E`, and `H` is uniquely differentiable on its entire range.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} [inst : NontriviallyNormedField 𝕜] {E : Type u_2} [inst_1 : NormedAddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : NormedSpace 𝕜 E] {H : Type u_3} [inst_3 : TopologicalSpace H] (I : ModelWithCorners 𝕜 E H),
  UniqueDiffOn 𝕜 (Set.range ↑I)
name: ModelWithCorners.unique_diff
docString: For any nontrivially normed field `𝕜`, normed additive commutative group `E`, normed space `E` over `𝕜`, and topological space `H`, the function `I` from `𝕜` to `E` defined in a Model With Corners `I` of types `𝕜`, `E`, and `H` is uniquely differentiable on its entire range.

This theorem, `RatFunc.denom_zero`, states that for any type `K`, which is a field, the denominator of the zero rational function (`RatFunc 0`) is equal to `1`. In other words, in any field, the denominator of the rational function representing zero is normalized to be the monic polynomial `1`.

type: ∀ {K : Type u} [inst : Field K], RatFunc.denom 0 = 1
name: RatFunc.denom_zero
docString: This theorem, `RatFunc.denom_zero`, states that for any type `K`, which is a field, the denominator of the zero rational function (`RatFunc 0`) is equal to `1`. In other words, in any field, the denominator of the rational function representing zero is normalized to be the monic polynomial `1`.

The default priority for spawned tasks, also the lowest priority: `0`.

type: Task.Priority
name: Task.Priority.default
docString: The default priority for spawned tasks, also the lowest priority: `0`.

If a type is both empty and a fintype, then its cardinality is zero.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : Fintype α] [inst_1 : IsEmpty α], Fintype.card α = 0
name: Fintype.card_of_isEmpty
docString: If a type is both empty and a fintype, then its cardinality is zero.

This theorem states that for any topological space `α` and any discrete topological space `Y`, if `α` is preconnected and `f` is a continuous function from `α` to `Y`, then the function `f` will produce the same output for any two inputs `x` and `y` from `α`. This is a version of `isPreconnected.constant` theorem specialized for `PreconnectedSpace`.

type:
∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] {Y : Type u_3} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] [inst_2 : DiscreteTopology Y],
  PreconnectedSpace α → ∀ {f : α → Y}, Continuous f → ∀ {x y : α}, f x = f y
name: PreconnectedSpace.constant
docString: This theorem states that for any topological space `α` and any discrete topological space `Y`, if `α` is preconnected and `f` is a continuous function from `α` to `Y`, then the function `f` will produce the same output for any two inputs `x` and `y` from `α`. This is a version of `isPreconnected.constant` theorem specialized for `PreconnectedSpace`.

Checks that `id` has not already been `#align`ed or `#noalign`ed.

type: {m : Type → Type} → [inst : Monad m] → [inst : Lean.MonadEnv m] → [inst : Lean.MonadError m] → Lean.Name → m Unit
name: Mathlib.Prelude.Rename.ensureUnused
docString: Checks that `id` has not already been `#align`ed or `#noalign`ed.

A `PreconnectedSpace` version of `isPreconnected.constant`

type:
∀ {α : Type u} [inst : TopologicalSpace α] {Y : Type u_3} [inst_1 : TopologicalSpace Y] [inst_2 : DiscreteTopology Y],
  PreconnectedSpace α → ∀ {f : α → Y}, Continuous f → ∀ {x y : α}, f x = f y
name: PreconnectedSpace.constant
docString: A `PreconnectedSpace` version of `isPreconnected.constant`

Default definition of `min`.

type: {α : Type u} → [inst : LE α] → [inst : DecidableRel fun x x_1 => x ≤ x_1] → α → α → α
name: minDefault
docString: Default definition of `min`.

A solution is `1` or `-1` if and only if `y = 0`.

type: ∀ {d : ℤ} {a : Pell.Solution₁ d}, a = 1 ∨ a = -1 ↔ Pell.Solution₁.y a = 0
name: Pell.Solution₁.eq_one_or_neg_one_iff_y_eq_zero
docString: A solution is `1` or `-1` if and only if `y = 0`.

specialized cases distinction for an arrow in the category of 0-length type vectors

type:
{β : TypeVec.Arrow Fin2.elim0 Fin2.elim0 → Sort u_1} →
  β TypeVec.nilFun → (f : TypeVec.Arrow Fin2.elim0 Fin2.elim0) → β f
name: TypeVec.typevecCasesNil₂
docString: specialized cases distinction for an arrow in the category of 0-length type vectors

`className` is the name of the class we are looking for.

type: Simps.AutomaticProjectionData → Lean.Name
name: Simps.AutomaticProjectionData.className
docString: `className` is the name of the class we are looking for.

cases distinction for an arrow in the category of 0-length type vectors

type:
{β : (v : TypeVec.{u_2} 0) → (v' : TypeVec.{u_3} 0) → TypeVec.Arrow v v' → Sort u_1} →
  β Fin2.elim0 Fin2.elim0 TypeVec.nilFun →
    (v : TypeVec.{u_2} 0) → (v' : TypeVec.{u_3} 0) → (fs : TypeVec.Arrow v v') → β v v' fs
name: TypeVec.typevecCasesNil₃
docString: cases distinction for an arrow in the category of 0-length type vectors

**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

type:
∀ {𝕜 : Type u_1} {E : Type u_2} {β : Type u_4} [inst : LinearOrderedField 𝕜] [inst_1 : AddCommGroup E]
  [inst_2 : LinearOrderedAddCommGroup β] [inst_3 : Module 𝕜 E] [inst_4 : Module 𝕜 β] [inst_5 : OrderedSMul 𝕜 β]
  {f : E → β} {x y z : E}, ConcaveOn 𝕜 (segment 𝕜 x y) f → z ∈ segment 𝕜 x y → min (f x) (f y) ≤ f z
name: ConcaveOn.min_le_of_mem_segment
docString:
**Minimum principle** for concave functions on a segment. If a function `f` is concave on the
segment `[x, y]`, then the eventual minimum of `f` on `[x, y]` is at `x` or `y`.

`proveEqZeroUsing tac e` tries to use `tac` to construct a proof of `e = 0`.

type: Lean.Elab.Tactic.TacticM Unit → Lean.Expr → Lean.MetaM Lean.Expr
name: Linarith.proveEqZeroUsing
docString: `proveEqZeroUsing tac e` tries to use `tac` to construct a proof of `e = 0`.

The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.

type: (R : Type u_1) → (M : Type u_2) → [inst : Semiring R] → [inst_1 : AddCommGroup M] → [inst : Module R M] → ℕ
name: FiniteDimensional.finrank
docString:
The rank of a module as a natural number.

Defined by convention to be `0` if the space has infinite rank.

For a vector space `M` over a field `R`, this is the same as the finite dimension
of `M` over `R`.

Corresponds to `norm_zero`.

type:
∀ {ι : Type u_2} {β : ι → Type u_3} [inst : Fintype ι] [inst_1 : (i : ι) → DecidableEq (β i)]
  [inst_2 : (i : ι) → Zero (β i)], hammingNorm 0 = 0
name: hammingNorm_zero
docString: Corresponds to `norm_zero`.

The minimum operation: `min x y`.

type: {α : Type u} → [self : Min α] → α → α → α
name: Min.min
docString: The minimum operation: `min x y`.

A type endowed with `0` and unary `-` is an `NegZeroClass`, if it admits an
injective map that preserves `0` and unary `-` to an `NegZeroClass`.

type:
{M₁ : Type u_1} →
  {M₂ : Type u_2} →
    [inst : Zero M₁] →
      [inst_1 : Neg M₁] →
        [inst_2 : NegZeroClass M₂] →
          (f : M₁ → M₂) → Function.Injective f → f 0 = 0 → (∀ (x : M₁), f (-x) = -f x) → NegZeroClass M₁
name: Function.Injective.negZeroClass
docString:
A type endowed with `0` and unary `-` is an `NegZeroClass`, if it admits an
injective map that preserves `0` and unary `-` to an `NegZeroClass`.

cases distinction for 0-length type vector

type: {β : TypeVec.{u_2} 0 → Sort u_1} → β Fin2.elim0 → (v : TypeVec.{u_2} 0) → β v
name: TypeVec.casesNil
docString: cases distinction for 0-length type vector

Semigroup homomorphism between the function spaces `I → α` and `I → β`, induced by a semigroup
homomorphism `f` between `α` and `β`.

type: {α : Type u_3} → {β : Type u_4} → [inst : Mul α] → [inst_1 : Mul β] → (α →ₙ* β) → (I : Type u_5) → (I → α) →ₙ* I → β
name: MulHom.compLeft
docString:
Semigroup homomorphism between the function spaces `I → α` and `I → β`, induced by a semigroup
homomorphism `f` between `α` and `β`.

Auxiliary function for `getRawProjections`.
Generates the default projection, and looks for a custom projection declared by the user,
and replaces the default projection with the custom one, if it can find it.

type: Lean.Name → Simps.ParsedProjectionData → List Lean.Level → Lean.CoreM Simps.ParsedProjectionData
name: Simps.findProjection
docString:
Auxiliary function for `getRawProjections`.
Generates the default projection, and looks for a custom projection declared by the user,
and replaces the default projection with the custom one, if it can find it.

The chromatic number of a graph is the minimal number of colors needed to color it.
This is `⊤` (infinity) iff `G` isn't colorable with finitely many colors.

If `G` is colorable, then `ENat.toNat G.chromaticNumber` is the `ℕ`-valued chromatic number.

type: {V : Type u} → SimpleGraph V → ℕ∞
name: SimpleGraph.chromaticNumber
docString:
The chromatic number of a graph is the minimal number of colors needed to color it.
This is `⊤` (infinity) iff `G` isn't colorable with finitely many colors.

If `G` is colorable, then `ENat.toNat G.chromaticNumber` is the `ℕ`-valued chromatic number.

Principal segment version of the `typein` function, embedding a well order into
ordinals as a principal segment.

type: {α : Type u} → (r : α → α → Prop) → [inst : IsWellOrder α r] → r ≺i fun x x_1 => x < x_1
name: Ordinal.typein.principalSeg
docString:
Principal segment version of the `typein` function, embedding a well order into
ordinals as a principal segment.
